title: Wandlebury Country Park Walking Route

images.title: Duncan Grey / The Lodge at the entrance to Wandlebury
images.caption: The Lodge at the entrance to Wandlebury with a view of the spacious on site car park in the background

images.title: Duncan Grey / Archway House, Wandlebury
images.caption: Archway House, Wandlebury. The grave of the Godolphin Barb horse, which died in 1753, can be seen under the archway. Maps and leaflets are available from the porch at all times and from a shed in car park on summer Sundays.

images.title: Simon Judd / Cupola Stable Block, Wandlebury Ring
images.caption: The 18th century Cupola stable block at Wandlebury Ring. The clock has only one hand on each of its four faces. The Wandlebury Estate was acquired by the Cambridge Preservation Society in 1954. The House, home of  Francis Godolphin, 2nd Earl of Godolphin, stood within the Ring. It has since been demolished but this monumental stable block remains, now used for accommodation and as headquarters office of Cambridge Past Present & Future. The society runs the nature reserve on Wandlebury Hill.

images.title: Sebastian Ballard, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Tadlow Granary - Wandlebury. "Report on the tree-ring dating of oak timbers from a granary of plank and muntin construction to the period 1415-1425. The granary was dismantled in 1971, and repaired and re-erected at the Cambridge Preservation Society's country park at Wandlebury, Stapleford, southeast of Cambridge, in 1981."

images.title: Sebastian Ballard, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Disabled access to the site. The driveway leads round to parking next to the cottages and information centre.

images.title: Sebastian Ballard, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The Games Area. Just outside the Wandlebury ring. Served as a bowling green in the 1840s and later as a cricket pitch for the servants.

images.title: Sebastian Ballard, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Wooded chalk grassland. A relatively unspoilt patch of vegetation just outside the Wandlebury ring. It has not been cut or grazed for many years and a variety of wild species of flowers and grasses have now established themselves here.

images.title: Sebastian Ballard, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Path in the iron age ditch. The area was already inhabited during the Bronze Age and around 2500 years ago there was an Iron Age hill fort known as Wandlebury Ring. This hill fort once had concentric ditches and earthen walls which were kept in place by wooden palisades. Although the fort has vanished, the ditch (the Ring) dug around the edge can clearly be seen and walked along, being 5 metres deep in places and offering an adventurous route along its edge.

description: This walk takes you around the delightful Wandlebury Country Park in Cambridge . The park is part of the Gog Magog Hills , a ridge of low chalk hills extending for several miles to the southeast of Cambridge. The park includes Wandlebury Hill where an Iron Age Hill Fort once stood. You can climb to the top for fine views over the Cambridgeshire countryside. Wandlebury is also a Nature Reserve and is perfect for bird watching. Other features include a picturesque beech avenue, highland cattle and beautiful wildflower meadows in the summer months. Please not cycling is not permitted in the park.
